S2) showed that remdesivir also inhibited virus infection efficiently in a human cell line (human liver cancer Huh-7 cells), which is sensitive to 2019-nCoV.2 Chloroquine, a widely-used anti-malarial and autoimmune disease drug, has recently been reported as a potential broad-spectrum antiviral drug.8,9 Chloroquine is known to block virus infection by increasing endosomal pH required for virus/cell fusion, as well as interfering with the glycosylation of cellular receptors of SARS-CoV.10 Our time-of-addition assay demonstrated that chloroquine functioned at both entry, and at post-entry stages of the 2019-nCoV infection in Vero E6 cells (Fig.

Notably, two compounds remdesivir (EC50 = 0.77 μM; CC50 > 100 μM; SI > 129.87) and chloroquine (EC50 = 1.13 μM; CC50 > 100 μM, SI > 88.50) potently blocked virus infection at low-micromolar concentration and showed high SI (Fig.
explanation: The evidence provides experimental data showing that both Remdesivir and Chloroquine effectively inhibit the recently emerged novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) in vitro. The EC50 values for both compounds are below 1.5 micromolar, indicating their potency in blocking virus infection.

statement: Washington state group is 1st to sue fox new for calling the coronavirus a hoax
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: According to the suit, Fox News violated the CPA by falsely and deceptively disseminating News via cable news contracts that the coronavirus was a hoax, and that it was otherwise not a danger to public health and safety. At least one poll has found that Fox News viewers were less likely to take precautions against the virus (including social distancing, handwashing, and other measures) seriously, and an open letter to Fox News from a group of journalism professors said misinformation that reaches the Fox News audience is a danger to public health. Based on the statements made, and the subsequent departure of Trish Regan, WASHLITE does present a cognizable theory of liability.

I said it was a hoax for them to be using it as a bludgeon on Trump. Notably, he made this denial in response to criticism from 74 journalism professors who wrote an open letter to Fox claiming that coverage of the coronavirus from Fox News Channel "is a danger to public health."

But when you get to the point where you are endangering the community  that transcends the limits of the First Amendment. When reached by phone for comment, Catherine Clark, a Seattle attorney who volunteered to join the plaintiffs legal team after reading an initial news account, said this is a case of national importance. A supporter of First Amendment protections, she continued, When it comes to the public health, safety, and welfare, it seems to me a different set of rules apply. In a statement, Fox News general counsel Lily Fu Clafee responded to the suit by saying: Wrong on the facts, frivolous on the law.
explanation: The claim is that a Washington state group sued Fox News for calling the coronavirus a hoax. The evidence provides details of a lawsuit against Fox News alleging they falsely and deceptively disseminated information that the coronavirus was a hoax, and this statement endangered public health. This suggests that there was indeed a lawsuit filed by a Washington state group.

statement: Unfounded fears that dogs can spread covid-19 can cause harm
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: And, although no evidence exists to indicate that they can either transmit the virus or develop its associated coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), fear among the public that pets might play a role in spreading COVID-19 has resulted in pets being abandoned or even killed.
At this time, there is no evidence that companion animals play a significant role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19; however, we are still learning about this virus.

According to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), there is no justification in taking measures against companion animals that may compromise their welfare, such as harming them, abandoning them, or euthanizing them based on unfounded fears over COVID-19.
explanation: The claim 'Unfounded fears that dogs can spread covid-19 can cause harm' is supported by the evidence provided because it mentions 'fear among the public that pets might play a role in spreading COVID-19 has resulted in pets being abandoned or even killed.' This indicates that unfounded fears about pets and the virus can indeed lead to harm.

statement: 1 million pc owners combine their gpu power to fight covid-19
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Almost two decades after it first launched, the uniquely decentralized structure of Folding@home is bringing together more people and computing power than ever to help understand, and hopefully fight, the COVID-19 threat.

Users around the world have donated processing power of over one million personal computers to help Folding@Homea distributed computing project for simulating protein dynamicsto search for new therapies for the coronavirus.
explanation: The evidence indicates that over one million personal computers have been donated to Folding@home, a distributed computing project used to simulate protein dynamics, which is being used in an effort to find new therapies for the coronavirus (COVID-19). While it does not explicitly state that these PC owners are combining their GPU power to fight COVID-19, the implication is clear as Folding@home relies on individual computers' processing power. Therefore, the claim can be supported.

statement: Inactivating porcine coronavirus before nuclei acid isolation with the temperature higher than 56 °c damages its genome integrity seriously
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Our results showed that only 50.11% of the detectable viral templates left after the inactivation of 56 °C for 30 minutes and only 3.36% left after the inactivation of 92 °C for 5 minutes when the samples were preserved by Hanks solution, one of an isotonic salt solutions currently suggested.

According to The Laboratory Technical Guidelines for Detection 2019-nCoV (Fourth Edition) issued by National Health and Commission of China and The Experts Consensus on Nucleic Acid Detection of 2019-nCoV released by Chinese Society of Laboratory Medicine, the human samples must be placed under 56°C or higher to inactivate the viruses in order to keep the inspectors from virus infection before the nucleic acids were isolated as the template of qRT-PCR.

We therefore highly recommend to carry out systematic investigation on the impact of high temperature inactivation on the integrity of 2019-nCoV genome and develop a sample preservation solution to protect the detectable templates of 2019-nCoV nucleic acids from high temperature inactivation damage.

However, the detectable templates of viral nucleic acids can be unchanged after the samples were incubated at 56 °C or higher if the samples were preserved with an optimized solution to protect the RNA from being disrupted.
explanation: The claim is supported by the evidence provided in the text. The evidence states that inactivating porcine coronavirus at 56 °C for 30 minutes significantly reduces its detectable viral templates and further suggests that higher temperatures such as 92 °C for 5 minutes cause even more damage to the genome integrity. Additionally, the text mentions that human samples must be placed under 56°C or higher to inactivate the viruses before nucleic acid isolation for qRT-PCR. The evidence also suggests that an optimized solution can protect the RNA from being disrupted at high temperatures.

statement: Therapeutic anticoagulation is associated with decreased mortality in mechanically ventilated covid-19 patients
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: A multivariate Cox proportional hazard regression model with PS weights to adjust for baseline differences found a 79% reduction in death in patients who were therapeutically anticoagulated HR 0.209, [95% Cl (0.10, 0.46), p < 0.001].

Results Propensity score (PS) weighted Kaplan-Meier plot demonstrated a survival advantage (57% vs. 25%) at 35 days from admission to the ICU in patients who received therapeutic anticoagulation for a minimum of 5 days compared to those who received prophylactic anticoagulation during their hospital course.
Conclusions Therapeutic anticoagulation is associated with a survival advantage among patients with COVID-19 who require mechanical ventilation in the ICU.
explanation: The provided evidence presents a statistical analysis (multivariate Cox proportional hazard regression model) that shows a significant reduction in death (79%) among mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients who received therapeutic anticoagulation compared to those receiving prophylactic anticoagulation. The Kaplan-Meier plot also demonstrates a survival advantage for the group receiving therapeutic anticoagulation.

statement: Sars-cov-2 is an unrestricted bioweapon
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: It also strengthens our earlier assertion that SARS-CoV-2 is a product of laboratory modification, which can be created in approximately six months using a template virus owned by a laboratory of the People's Liberation Army (PLA).
We therefore define SARS- CoV-2 as an Unrestricted Bioweapon and the current pandemic a result of Unrestricted Biowarfare.
Importantly, while SARS-CoV-2 meets the criteria of a bioweapon specified by the PLA, its impact is well beyond what is conceived for a typical bioweapon.
explanation: The evidence provided does not substantiate the claim that SARS-CoV-2 is an unrestricted bioweapon. The statement suggests SARS-CoV-2 was created in a Chinese laboratory and quickly developed, but this alone does not prove it's an unrestricted bioweapon or result of biowarfare. Further evidence is required to establish the intent and purpose behind its creation.

statement: Mosaic rbd nanoparticles elicit neutralizing antibodies against sars-cov-2 and zoonotic coronaviruses
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Mice immunized with RBD-nanoparticles, but not soluble antigen, elicited cross-reactive antibody binding and neutralization responses, confirming increased immunogenicity from multimerization.

Mosaic-RBD-nanoparticles elicited antibodies with superior cross-reactive recognition of heterologous RBDs compared to sera from immunizations with homotypic SARS-CoV-2RBD-nanoparticles or antibodies from COVID-19 convalescent human plasmas.
Thus, a single immunization with mosaic-RBD- nanoparticles provides a potential strategy to simultaneously protect against SARS-CoV-2 and emerging zoonotic coronaviruses.
explanation: The evidence shows that mice immunized with RBD-nanoparticles elicit cross-reactive antibody binding and neutralization responses against SARS-CoV-2 and other zoonotic coronaviruses. This suggests that Mosaic rbd nanoparticles indeed elicit neutralizing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 and zoonotic coronaviruses.

statement: South korean city deserted due to super spreading event

statement: Performance of vivadiagtm covid-19 igm/igg rapid test is inadequate for diagnosis of covid-19 in acute patients referring to emergency room department
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: On the basis of our results, VivaDiag COVID19 IgM/IgG Rapid Test LFIA is not recommended for triage of patients with suspected COVID19.

Indeed, the majority of patients that tested positive for COVID19 by realtime RTPCR would have been identified as negative using only the rapid serological assay, leading to a misdiagnosis of COVID19 disease in the vast majority of patients.

Such low sensitivity leads to non-diagnosis of most patients, which is why the authors do not recommend the use of the COVID-19 IgM/IgG VivaDiagTM rapid test for triage of patients with suspected COVID-19 in emergency department.

This means it may not accurately identify most patients with COVID-19, leading to misdiagnosis. Therefore, the test performance is considered inadequate for diagnosis of COVID-19 in acute patients referring to an emergency room department.

statement: Cetylpyridinium chloride-containing mouthwashes reduce in vitro sars-cov-2 infectivity.
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: A common compound in mouthwashes found to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 in vitro.
CPC- containing mouth rinses could represent a cost-effective measure to reduce SARS-CoV-2 infectivity in saliva, aiding to reduce viral transmission from infected individuals.
Here we show that Cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC), a quaternary ammonium compound present in many oral mouthwashes, reduces SARS-CoV-2 infectivity by inhibiting viral fusion with target cells.

Antiviral activity of CPC-containing mouthwashes inhibiting SARS-CoV-2 entry.

statement: Symptom-based screening process was ineffective in detecting sars-cov-2 infection during evacuation of 126 people from wuhan , china .
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: In fact, the researchers noted "epidemiologic uncertainty regarding possible transmission of the virus by asymptomatic or subclinically symptomatic infected persons" and that it is also not clear "whether persons who show no signs or symptoms of respiratory infections shed SARS-CoV2."

Aside from the ineffectiveness of the screening process, the authors found that the virus could potentially be spread by those who exhibited mild symptoms: Shedding of potentially infectious virus may occur in persons who have no fever and no signs or only minor signs of infection. Over 73,000 people around the world have been infected with the coronavirus, most of those cases in mainland China.
Nevertheless, the researchers concluded that the symptom-based screening process was "ineffective" at detecting cases of SARS-CoV2 infection.

In this effort to evacuate 126 people from Wuhan to Frankfurt, a symptom-based screening process was ineffective in detecting SARS-CoV-2 infection in 2 persons who later were found to have evidence of SARS-CoV-2 in a throat swab.

statement: Saliva is more sensitive for sars-cov-2 detection in covid-19 patients than nasopharyngeal swabs
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Saliva is a promising candidate for SARS-CoV-2 diagnostics because (1) collection is minimally invasive and can reliably be self-administered and (2) saliva has exhibited comparable sensitivity to nasopharyngeal swabs in detection of other respiratory pathogens, including endemic human coronaviruses, in previous studies.

When we compared SARS-CoV-2 detection from patient-matched nasopharyngeal and saliva samples, we found that saliva yielded greater detection sensitivity and consistency throughout the course of infection.

Taken together, our findings demonstrate that saliva is a viable and more sensitive alternative to nasopharyngeal swabs and could enable at-home self-administered sample collection for accurate large- scale SARS-CoV-2 testing.

To validate the use of saliva for SARS-CoV-2 detection, we tested nasopharyngeal and saliva samples from confirmed COVID-19 patients and self-collected samples from healthcare workers on COVID-19 wards.
explanation: The claim suggests that Saliva is more sensitive for SARS-CoV-2 detection in Covid-19 patients than nasopharyngeal swabs. The evidence provides multiple reasons supporting this claim: (1) Saliva collection is less invasive and can be self-administered, (2) saliva has comparable sensitivity to nasopharyngeal swabs in detection of other respiratory pathogens, (3) a study comparing SARS-CoV-2 detection from patient-matched nasopharyngeal and saliva samples found that saliva yielded greater detection sensitivity and consistency, (4) the use of saliva for SARS-CoV-2 detection was validated by testing samples from confirmed COVID-19 patients and self-collected samples from healthcare workers on COVID-19 wards. Therefore, based on the given evidence, the claim is supported.

statement: Vitamin d sufficiency reduced risk for morbidity and mortality in covid-19 patients
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: This anti-inflammatory effect of vitamin D might prevent cytokine storm in COVID-19 patients and may explain the decreased risk of severity and mortality observed in our patients who were vitamin D sufficient.
The severity of clinical outcomes from COVID-19 and mortality were reduced in patients who were vitamin D sufficient.

Conclusion: Therefore, it is recommended that improving vitamin D status in the general population and in particular hospitalized patients has a potential benefit in reducing the severity of morbidities and mortality associated with acquiring COVID-19.

statement: A functional genomics approach to understand host genetic regulation of covid-19 severity
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: A functional genomics investigation based on functional characterization of individuals with high genetic risk for severe COVID-19 susceptibility identified several major patterns: i. a large impact of genetically determined innate immune responses in COVID-19, with increased susceptibility for severe disease in individuals with defective monocyte-derived cytokine production; ii.

Here, we employed the detailed clinical, immunological and multi-omics data of the Human Functional Genomics Projects (HFGP) to explore the physiological significance of the host genetic variants that influence susceptibility to severe COVID-19.
Our findings allow a physiological understanding of genetic susceptibility to severe COVID-19, and indicate pathways that could be targeted for prevention and therapy.
explanation: The claim is supported by the evidence as it discusses a functional genomics investigation to understand host genetic regulation of COVID-19 severity using data from the Human Functional Genomics Projects (HFGP). The evidence also shows that this investigation identified patterns related to innate immune responses and genetically determined cytokine production, which are directly relevant to understanding severe COVID-19 susceptibility.

statement: Strong link found between abnormal liver tests and poor covid-19 outcomes
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Rather than the liver itself driving poorer outcomes in COVID-19 patients, the organ is more likely a bystander affected by the hyperinflammation associated with COVID-19 and by the side effects of related treatments, Nathanson said.

But regardless of whether patients came to the hospital with existing liver problems or developed them during their COVID-19-related hospitalization, a strong association was observed between abnormal liver tests and the severity of the COVID-19 cases, the researchers said.
The study noted a relationship between drugs used to treat severe COVID-19 and liver damage, most significantly the drug tocilizumab.

We observed a strong association between the use of COVID-19 medications and abnormal liver tests, said Lim, but added that they could not confidently tease out that the abnormal tests were due to drug-induced liver injury as opposed to the disease.
explanation: The evidence indicates a strong association between abnormal liver tests and poor COVID-19 outcomes. Although it is not explicitly stated that the liver itself drives these poorer outcomes, the researchers observed this relationship in patients with existing liver problems or those who developed them during their hospitalization for COVID-19. Additionally, certain medications used to treat severe COVID-19 were found to be related to liver damage.

We observed a strong association between the use of COVID-19 medications and abnormal liver tests, said Lim, but added that they could not confidently tease out that the abnormal tests were due to drug-induced liver injury as opposed to the disease.

statement: The sars-cov-2 cytopathic effect is blocked with autophagy modulators
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: One Sentence Summary Blocking SARS-CoV-2 cytopathic effects with selective autophagy inhibitors underlying the clinical benefits of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine.

While it is known that chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, extensively explored as clinical agents for COVID-19, have multiple cellular effects including inhibiting autophagy, there are also dose- limiting toxicities in patients that make clearly establishing their potential mechanisms-of-action problematic.

Immunofluorescence staining for LC3B and LysoTracker dye staining assays in several cell lines indicated their potency and efficacy for inhibiting autophagy correlated with the measurements in the SARS-CoV-2 cytopathic effect assay.
explanation: The evidence shows that the effects of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine on SARS-CoV-2 are related to their ability to inhibit autophagy, as indicated by the immunofluorescence staining and LysoTracker dye staining assays. While this does not necessarily mean that all autophagy modulators would block the SARS-CoV-2 cytopathic effect, it does support the claim that some autophagy modulators, specifically chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, have this effect.

statement: Intranasal chadox1 ncov-19/azd1222 vaccination reduces shedding of sars-cov-2 d614g in rhesus macaques.
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Intranasal vaccination of rhesus macaques resulted in reduced shedding and a reduction in viral load in bronchoalveolar lavage and lower respiratory tract tissue.
Here we investigate whether intranasally administered ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 reduces shedding, using a SARS-CoV-2 virus with the D614G mutation in the spike protein.
In conclusion, intranasal vaccination reduced shedding in two different SARS-CoV-2 animal models, justifying further investigation as a potential vaccination route for COVID-19 vaccines.
explanation: The evidence indicates that the intranasal administration of ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 vaccine in rhesus macaques resulted in reduced shedding and lower viral load, specifically in bronchoalveolar lavage and lower respiratory tract tissue. Additionally, this reduction was observed with two different SARS-CoV-2 animal models, one of which had the D614G mutation in the spike protein. These findings support the claim that intranasal ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 vaccination reduces shedding of SARS-CoV-2 (D614G) in rhesus macaques.

statement: Exhaled aerosol increases with covid-19 infection , and risk factors of disease symptom severity
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: In our observational cohort study of the exhaled breath particles of 74 healthy human subjects, and in our experimental infection study of eight nonhuman primates infected by aerosol with SARS- CoV-2, we found that exhaled aerosol particles increase one to three orders of magnitude with aging, high BMI, and COVID-19 infection.

We studied respiratory droplet generation and exhalation in human and nonhuman primate subjects with and without COVID-19 infection to explore whether SARS- CoV-2 infection, and other changes in physiological state, translates into observable evolution of numbers and sizes of exhaled respiratory droplets in healthy and diseased subjects.
explanation: The claim is supported by the evidence provided, which shows that exhaled aerosol particles increase with aging, high BMI, and COVID-19 infection in both human subjects and nonhuman primates infected with SARS-CoV-2.

statement: Autopsies show varied forms of heart damage in covid-19 patients
label: SUPPORTED

Early in the pandemic, other clinicians noted that even some patients who didn't have preexisting heart conditions experienced cardiovascular damage while fighting COVID-19 infections, pointing to a possible causative link.
But Stone says he was surprised to see just how common these were--18 out of 21 COVID-19 patients' hearts harbored macrophages that exhibited this type of inflammation.

statement: White house 's opening up america again guidelines
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: According to the White House, once these criteria are met, states and regions can begin returning to normal economic activity in three phases.
Titled "Opening Up America Again," the document lays out recommendations for easing stay-at-home restrictions for individuals, employers and organizations once a series of "gating criteria" are met.
Learn more about the guidelines at WhiteHouse.gov/OpeningAmerica.

This evening, President Trump continued his unprecedented level of access to the American people at a press conference where he presented his guidelines on the three phases of Opening Up America Again.

During a virtual leadership roundtable hosted by Meeting Professionals International, held during Virtual Global Meetings Industry Day  two days before the White House released the "Opening Up America Again" guidelines  U.S. Travel Association CEO Roger Dow described how he and other industry leaders have started discussing specific guidelines for events once gatherings are again allowed to take place.
explanation: The evidence provided indicates that the White House has released guidelines titled 'Opening Up America Again,' which provide recommendations for easing stay-at-home restrictions for individuals, employers, and organizations once a series of criteria are met. The document was presented by President Trump, as stated in the evidence.

statement: Mva vector vaccines inhibit sars cov-2 replication in upper and lower respiratory tracts of transgenic mice and prevent lethal disease.
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: In a transgenic mouse model, one or two injections of recombinant MVAs that express modified forms of S inhibited CoV-2 replication in the upper and lower respiratory tracts and prevented severe disease.

A recent paper, that appeared as a preprint on the bioRxiv server in January 2021, shows the effectiveness of a novel recombinant vaccinia virus that expresses modified SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen, in preventing the replication of the virus in the respiratory tract of transgenic mice, and to prevent lethal disease.
The researchers found that serum from mice vaccinated with MVA that expressed wildtype S could be given intraperitoneally to transgenic hACE2-expressing mice, producing a high neutralizing titer.
Weight loss and lethality following intranasal infection of transgenic hACE2 mice with CoV-2 was prevented by one or two immunizations with rMVAs or by passive transfer of serum from vaccinated mice.
explanation: The claim is supported by the evidence provided. The evidence shows that a recombinant MVA vaccine expressing modified SARS-CoV-2 spike antigen was effective in inhibiting CoV-2 replication in the respiratory tracts of transgenic mice and preventing lethal disease.

statement: Sars-cov-2 orf6 hijacks nup98 to block stat nuclear import and antagonize interferon signaling
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: The Orf6-Nup98 interaction is critical to block STAT nuclear translocation and IFN signaling.
The Orf6-Nup98 interaction is critical to block STAT nuclear translocation and IFN signaling. Fig.
In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs).

We found that SARS-CoV-2 Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import.
explanation: The claim states that Sars-cov-2 Orf6 hijacks nup98 to block stat nuclear import and antagonize interferon signaling. The provided evidence shows the interaction between SARS-CoV-2 Orf6 and Nup98-Rae1 is critical in impairing docking of cargo-receptor complexes and disrupting nuclear import, which directly relates to blocking STAT nuclear translocation and IFN signaling.

statement: Sars-cov-2 orf6 hijacks nup98 to induce stat nuclear import and antagonize interferon signaling
label: NOT_SUPPORTED
evidences: The Orf6-Nup98 interaction is critical to block STAT nuclear translocation and IFN signaling.
The Orf6-Nup98 interaction is critical to block STAT nuclear translocation and IFN signaling. Fig.
In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs).

We found that SARS-CoV-2 Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import.
explanation: The evidence presented in the text supports the claim that SARS-cov-2 orf6 hijacks nup98 to induce STAT nuclear import and antagonize interferon signaling. The evidence shows that Orf6 interacts with Nup98-Rae1 at the nuclear pore complex, which is critical for blocking STAT nuclear translocation and IFN signaling.

statement: Normally invisible saliva droplets can linger in the air , visualized by researchers using laser technology .
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: He runs a laser lab normally used to study protein structural dynamics, but was able to use that technology to investigate the hunch that normal speaking produces small droplets that can spread disease.

Whereas large droplets fall quickly to the ground, small droplets can dehydrate and linger as droplet nuclei in the air, where they behave like an aerosol and thereby expand the spatial extent of emitted infectious particles.2 We report the results of a laser light-scattering experiment in which speech-generated droplets and their trajectories were visualized.

Laser light is a common technique to visualize and count droplets in the air, says Alex Huffman, an associate professor who studies aerosols in the department of chemistry and biochemistry at the University of Denver.

Image Laser light scattering observations of droplets in the experimental setup.Credit...Valentyn Stadnytskyi; Philip Anfinrud; Christina E. Bax; Adriaan Bax The scientists also found that while droplets start shrinking from dehydration as soon as they leave a persons mouth, they can still float in the air for eight to 14 minutes.
explanation: The evidence provides results of a laser light-scattering experiment conducted by researchers to visualize and count droplets in the air produced during speaking. This technique is described as a common method for observing and counting airborne droplets. The experimental findings also report that these small droplets can dehydrate, linger in the air, and behave like an aerosol. These observations support the claim that normally invisible saliva droplets can linger in the air when visualized by laser technology.

statement: Sex differences in immune responses to sars-cov-2 that underlie disease outcomes
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: In this study, we examined sex differences in viral loads, SARS-CoV-2-specific antibody titers, plasma cytokines, as well as blood cell phenotyping in COVID-19 patients.
Conversely, higher innate immune cytokines in female patients associated with worse disease progression, but not in male patients.
In contrast, female patients mounted significantly more robust T cell activation than male patients during SARS-CoV-2 infection, which was sustained in old age.
explanation: The provided evidence discusses a study on sex differences in immune responses to SARS-CoV-2, examining viral loads, antibody titers, cytokines, and blood cell phenotyping in COVID-19 patients. The study shows that female patients had higher innate immune cytokines associated with worse disease progression but sustained T cell activation during SARS-CoV-2 infection compared to male patients. This supports the claim of sex differences in immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 that underlie disease outcomes.

Additionally, the study suggests that higher innate immune cytokines in female patients are associated with worse disease progression, but not in male patients, and that female patients mount significantly more robust T cell activation during SARS-CoV-2 infection, which is sustained in old age. statement: Adjuvant-free nanofiber vaccine induces in situ lung dendritic cell activation and th17 responses
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: These observations are congruent with the conclusion of independent priming by intranasal EαQ11 nanofibers of CD4+ T cells in the lung.
Thus, in the absence of exogenous adjuvants, intranasally administered nanofiber vaccines preferentially elicit robust antigen-specific TH17 responses that accumulated in both the LN and lung.

During primary immune responses elicited by pathogens such as Gram-negative bacteria, IL-17 at the lung mucosal surface is produced by natural killer (NK) cells, γδ T cells, and group 3 innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) [reviewed in ( 35)].
explanation: The evidence indicates that the intranasal administration of EαQ11 nanofibers without adjuvants can induce antigen-specific TH17 responses in the lung and lymph nodes. The evidence also suggests that during primary immune responses to Gram-negative bacteria, IL-17 is produced by cells such as NK cells, γδ T cells, and ILCs. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the nanofiber vaccine induces in situ lung dendritic cell activation and TH17 responses.

statement: Antibody testing will enhance the power and accuracy of covid-19-prevention trials
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Knowing that someone seroconverts and becomes immune during the trial despite having no symptoms could, for instance, prove to be a more optimal outcome than simply preventing infection and the development of immunity altogether, as has been observed in some patients receiving chemoprophylaxis for influenza8.
Here we argue that serological testing of trial participants at the start and end of the trial (and perhaps at intermediate points) will enhance the value and interpretability of these studies.
explanation: The evidence suggests that serological testing can provide additional information on immunity status, even in asymptomatic individuals, which could be valuable in COVID-19 prevention trials. This is because it allows for the identification of individuals who have developed immunity despite not showing symptoms, which may be more indicative of the trial's efficacy.

label: SUPPORTED

statement: Sars-cov-2 infects brain choroid plexus and disrupts the blood-csf-barrier
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: We find that infected cells of the choroid plexus are an apolipoprotein and ACE2 expressing subset of epithelial barrier cells.

These findings suggest that neurological complications may result from effects on the choroid plexus, an important barrier that normally prevents entry of immune cells and cytokines into the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and brain.

We then challenge organoids with both SARS-CoV-2 spike protein pseudovirus and live virus to demonstrate high viral tropism for choroid plexus epithelial cells but not stromal cells, and little to no infection of neurons or glia.
Here, we use brain organoids to examine SARS-CoV-2 neurotropism.
Finally, we show that infection with live SARS-CoV-2 leads to barrier breakdown of the choroid plexus.
explanation: The evidence provides multiple lines of support for the claim that SARS-CoV-2 infects brain choroid plexus and disrupts the blood-CSF-barrier: (1) The choroid plexus is found to be an Apolipoprotein and ACE2 expressing subset of epithelial barrier cells, suggesting susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection. (2) Both pseudovirus and live virus are demonstrated to infect choroid plexus epithelial cells but not stromal cells or neurons/glia. (3) Infection with live SARS-CoV-2 leads to barrier breakdown of the choroid plexus.

statement: Leronlimab used in seven patients in nyc with severe covid-19 demonstrated promise with two intubated patients in icu , removed from icu and extubated with reduced pulmonary inflammation
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Our companion diagnostics showed that after three days of therapy, the immune profile in these patients approached normal levels and the levels of cytokines involved in the cytokine storm were much improved. Jacob Lalezari, M.D., Interim Chief Medical Officer of CytoDyn, commented, These preliminary results give hope that leronlimab may help hospitalized patients with COVID-19 recover from the pulmonary inflammation that drives mortality and the need for ventilators.
The treatment with leronlimab is targeted as a therapy for patients who experience respiratory complications as a result of contracting SARS-CoV-2 causing the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19).

Moreover, a Phase 2b clinical trial demonstrated that leronlimab monotherapy can prevent viral escape in HIV-infected patients; some patients on leronlimab monotherapy have remained virally suppressed for more than five years.
Clinical results to date from multiple trials have shown that leronlimab can significantly reduce viral burden in people infected with HIV with no reported drug-related serious adverse events (SAEs).
explanation: The evidence provided does not specify the number and condition of COVID-19 patients treated with leronlimab in NYC nor does it confirm any specific improvement like two intubated patients being removed from ICU or reduced pulmonary inflammation. While the evidence suggests that leronlimab may help improve immune response, reduce cytokine storms, and potentially prevent viral escape in HIV-infected patients, more specific data is needed to verify the claim.

statement: The sars-cov-2-like virus found in captive pangolins from guangdong should be better sequenced .
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: bioRxiv - Bioinformatics Pub Date : 2020-05-07 , DOI: 10.1101/2020.05.07.077016 Alexandre Hassanin Viruses closely related to SARS-CoV-2, which is the virus responsible of the Covid-19 pandemic, were sequenced in several Sunda pangolins ( Manis javanica ) seized in the Guangdong and Guangxi provinces of China between 2017 and 20191-3.
The GD/P2S dataset2 contains reads that are identical to SARS-CoV-2, suggesting either the coexistence of two SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the same pangolin or contamination by the human virus.
To overcome this absence, I assembled these genomes from the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) data available for SARS- CoV-2-like viruses detected in five captive pangolins from Guangdong.
explanation: The claim states that the SARS-CoV-2-like virus found in captive pangolins from Guangdong should be better sequenced. The provided evidence describes the sequencing of such viruses in pangolins seized between 2017 and 2019, suggesting that they were indeed sequenced, but the sequencing process could have room for improvement. Therefore, the claim is supported.

The GD/P2S dataset2 contains reads that are identical to SARS-CoV-2, suggesting either the coexistence of two SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the same pangolin or contamination by the human virus.
To overcome this absence, I assembled these genomes from the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) data available for SARS- CoV-2-like viruses detected in five captive pangolins from Guangdong.
explanation: The claim suggests that the SARS-CoV-2-like virus found in captive pangolins from Guangdong cannot be better sequenced. However, the provided evidence only indicates that the genomes of SARS-CoV-2-like viruses were assembled from Sequence Read Archive (SRA) data available for SARS-CoV-2-like viruses detected in five captive pangolins from Guangdong. The evidence does not provide information about whether this sequencing process can be considered the best method or if there are possibilities for improvement. Therefore, the claim cannot be definitively supported or refuted based on the given evidence.

statement: Sars-cov-2 spike protein promotes hyper-inflammatory response that can be ameliorated by spike-antagonistic peptide and fda-approved er stress and map kinase inhibitors in vitro
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: We developed an antagonistic peptide that inhibits S1-ACE2 interaction and CoV2-S1-induced productions of pro-inflammatory cytokines.

Here we demonstrate that 2019 SARS-CoV-2 spike protein subunit 1 (CoV2-S1) induces high levels of NF-κB activations, production of pro- inflammatory cytokines and mild epithelial damage, in human bronchial epithelial cells.
explanation: The evidence provided demonstrates that the S1-ACE2 interaction induces pro-inflammatory cytokines and NF-κB activations, which are markers of hyper-inflammatory response. The development of an antagonistic peptide that inhibits this interaction suggests a potential means to ameliorate the hyper-inflammatory response. Furthermore, the use of FDA-approved ER stress and MAP kinase inhibitors in vitro was shown to have an impact on this response, further supporting the claim.

label: NOT_SUPPORTED

Here we demonstrate that 2019 SARS-CoV-2 spike protein subunit 1 (CoV2-S1) induces high levels of NF-κB activations, production of pro- inflammatory cytokines and mild epithelial damage, in human bronchial epithelial cells.
explanation: The evidence provided does demonstrate that the S1 subunit of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein induces high levels of NF-κB activation and pro-inflammatory cytokine production in human bronchial epithelial cells, as well as mild epithelial damage. However, it does not show that a spike-antagonistic peptide or FDA-approved ER stress and MAP kinase inhibitors cannot ameliorate this hyper-inflammatory response in vitro.

label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Using lentiviral pseudotypes and a cell- culture adapted SARS-CoV-2 virus with a S1/S2 deletion, we show that the polybasic insertion is selected for in lung cells and primary human airway epithelial cultures but selected against in Vero E6, a cell line used for passaging SARS-CoV-2.
The furin cleavage site of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein is a key determinant for transmission
We find this selective advantage depends on expression of the cell surface protease, TMPRSS2, that allows virus entry independent of endosomes thus avoiding antiviral IFITM proteins.
SARS-CoV-2 has a unique polybasic insertion at the S1/S2 CS, which we demonstrate can be cleaved by furin.

The polybasic insertion can also be cleaved by furin. These findings collectively suggest that the furin cleavage site in SARS-CoV-2 spike protein plays a role in enhanced replication in airway cells and may contribute to its transmission.

statement: Is there an airborne component to the transmission of covid-19 ?
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Conclusions Given that live SARS-CoV-2 virions are known to be shed in high concentrations from the nasal cavity of both symptomatic and asymptomatic COVID-19 patients, the results suggest that those sharing enclosed spaces with infectors for long periods may be at risk of contracting COVID-19 by the aerosol route, even when practicing social distancing.
In order to quantify the risk posed by COVID-19 infectors exhaling respiratory aerosols in enclosed spaces, we undertook a computer modelling study to simulate transmission in an office building.

statement: Saliva-based antigen testing is better than the pcr swab
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: And, just as importantly, antigen-based testing is highly specific: unlike its PCR counterpart, the antigen test isnt fooled by faint signals of lingering viral matter outside the period of infectiousness.

Fortunately, other attributes of saliva-based antigen testing make this feasible: unlike PCR, it doesnt require trained personnel, specific chemical supplies, or centralized, expensive laboratory instrument; it is less vulnerable to the supply chain bottlenecks that plague PCR-based labs; it returns results in a matter of hours; it costs as little as $1 per test; and it could be as convenient as sucking on a piece of paper.

Rapid, saliva-based antigen testing is an essential weapon in the fight to resume many of the activities and reopen many of the venues that comprise what we used to call normal life. It is practical, convenient, cost-effective, and easily scaled.
explanation: The claim is not directly supported by the provided evidence. While the evidence discusses advantages of saliva-based antigen testing (ease of use, cost-effectiveness, and speed), it does not specifically compare these tests to PCR swab tests or state that one is 'better' than the other.

statement: Orf8 and orf3b antibodies are accurate serological markers of early and late sars-cov-2 infection
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: We identified new targets of the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 and show that nucleocapsid, open reading frame (ORF)8 and ORF3b elicit the strongest specific antibody responses.

We have identified ORF8 antibodies as a major marker of acute, convalescent and long-term antibody response to SARS-CoV-2 infection because of its immunodominance and specificity, in addition to N protein.
explanation: The evidence provided states that ORF8 and ORF3b are targets of the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 and that ORF8 antibodies are a major marker of acute, convalescent and long-term antibody response to SARS-CoV-2 infection. This suggests that ORF8 and ORF3b antibodies can be used as serological markers for early and late SARS-CoV-2 infections.

statement: Plasma from recovered covid19 subjects inhibits spike protein binding to ace2 in a microsphere-based inhibition assay
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Next, we find that plasma from all 22/24 subjects with anti-trimer IgGs inhibited ACE2-trimer binding to a greater degree than controls, and that the degree of inhibition correlated with anti-trimer IgG levels.
This inhibition assay may be broadly useful to quantify the functional antibody response of recovered COVID19 patients or vaccine recipients in a cell-free assay system.

Here we present microsphere-based Flow Cytometry assays that quantify both anti-spike IgGs in plasma, and the ability of plasma to inhibit the binding of spike protein to angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2).

statement: Bradykinin initiates cytokine-mediated inflammatory hyperalgesia
label: SUPPORTED

statement: Persistence of viral rna , pneumocyte syncytia and thrombosis are hallmarks of advanced covid-19 pathology
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Viral presence and immunopathology in patients with lethal COVID-19: a prospective autopsy cohort study.
COVID-19 and thrombotic or thromboembolic disease: implications for prevention, antithrombotic therapy, and follow-up.
explanation: The provided evidence consists of two studies that examine the pathology of COVID-19 in patients who died from the disease (1) and the implications of thrombosis associated with COVID-19 (2). The first study confirms the presence of viral RNA, which is consistent with persistent viral presence. The second study highlights thrombosis as a significant complication in advanced COVID-19 cases, and pneumocyte syncytia, or the fusing of alveolar epithelial cells into multinucleated giant cells in the lung tissue, is often associated with pathological conditions like viral infection and inflammation. These findings support the claim that persistence of viral RNA, pneumocyte syncytia, and thrombosis are hallmarks of advanced COVID-19 pathology.

The first study examines immunopathology in patients with lethal COVID-19, highlighting the presence of viral RNA and the role it plays in tissue damage. The second study discusses the link between COVID-19 and thrombotic or thromboembolic disease, providing evidence for the occurrence of blood clots as a part of advanced COVID-19 pathology.

statement: The novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 directly decimates human spleens and lymph nodes
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: The Novel Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) Directly Decimates Human Spleens and Lymph Nodes
SARS-CoV-2 infection induces severe tissue damage including lymph follicle depletion, splenic nodule atrophy, histiocyte hyperplasia and lymphocyte reductions.
The novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) directly decimates human spleens and lymph nodes.
explanation: The provided evidence shows that SARS-CoV-2 infection induces severe tissue damage in the spleen and lymph nodes, which includes depletion of lymph follicles, splenic nodule atrophy, histiocyte hyperplasia, and lymphocyte reductions. The word 'decimates' might be considered strong, but these observed effects can reasonably be understood as significant damage to these tissues, which aligns with the meaning of 'decimate'.

statement: Anakinra to prevent respiratory failure in covid-19
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Conclusions Early suPAR-guided anakinra treatment is associated with decrease of the risk for SRF and restoration of the pro- /anti-inflammatory balance.
We investigated if early suPAR (soluble urokinase plasminogen activator receptor)-guided anakinra treatment could prevent COVID-19-assocated SRF.

Anakinra treatment was associated with decrease in SOFA score and in circulating interleukin (IL)-6, sCD163 and sIL2-R; the serum IL-10/IL-6 ratio on day 7 was inversely associated with the change in SOFA score.
explanation: The claim is that Anakinra can prevent respiratory failure in COVID-19. The evidence provided suggests an investigation into whether early treatment with suPAR-guided Anakinra could prevent COVID-19-associated SRF (severe respiratory failure). The findings show that Anakinra treatment was associated with a decrease in SOFA score and several inflammatory markers, which is indicative of the successful prevention or mitigation of severe respiratory complications.

statement: Early transfusion of a large cohort of covid-19 patients with high titer anti-sars-cov-2 spike protein igg convalescent plasma confirms a signal of significantly decreased mortality
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: In the aggregate, the analysis confirms and extends our previous preliminary finding that transfusion of COVID-19 patients soon after hospitalization with high titer anti-spike protein RBD IgG present in convalescent plasma significantly reduces mortality.

Transfusion of convalescent plasma collected from donors who have recovered from COVID-19 disease has emerged as a promising therapy and has been granted emergency use authorization by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
With respect to altering mortality, our analysis identified an optimal window of 44 hours post-hospitalization for transfusing COVID-19 patients with high titer convalescent plasma.

We recently reported results from interim analysis of a propensity-score matched study suggesting that early treatment of COVID-19 patients with convalescent plasma containing high titer anti-spike protein receptor binding domain (RBD) IgG significantly decreases mortality.
explanation: The evidence provided indicates that early transfusion of a large cohort of COVID-19 patients with high titer anti-SARS-CoV-2 spike protein IgG convalescent plasma significantly reduces mortality. statement: High sars-cov-2 viral load is associated with a worse clinical outcome of covid-19 disease
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Here we report a statistically significant correlation between viral load and disease severity, being high viral load associated with worse clinical prognosis, independently of several previously identified risk factors such as age, sex, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, and lung disease (asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).
The data presented here reinforce the viral load as a potential biomarker for predicting disease severity in SARS-CoV-2-infected patients.
It is also an important parameter in viral evolution since it relates to the numbers and types of variant genomes present in a viral population, a potential determinant of disease progression.

statement: Evaluation of four commercial , fully automated sars-cov-2 antibody tests suggests a revision of the siemens sars-cov-2 igg assay
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Conclusions Thorough on-site evaluation of commercially available serologic tests for detection of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 remains imperative for laboratories.
The potentially impaired sensitivity of the Siemens COV2G necessitates a switch to the companys newly filed SARS-CoV-2 IgG assay (sCOVG) for follow-up studies.
ROC curve analyses suggest a lowering of the cut-off index for the Siemens COV2G assay.
Finally, the combination of two anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody assays is feasible when considering borderline reactive results.
explanation: The evidence presents conclusions suggesting that the Siemens COV2G assay may have impaired sensitivity, and it recommends switching to the company's newly filed SARS-CoV-2 IgG assay (sCOVG) for follow-up studies. Additionally, it suggests a lowering of the cut-off index for the Siemens COV2G assay, which could imply a revision is needed.

statement: Sars-cov1 frequent mask use in public venues , frequent hand washing , and disinfecting the living quarters were significant protective factors
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: In addition, frequent mask use in public venues, frequent hand washing, and disinfecting the living quarters were significant protective factors (OR 0.36 to 0.58).

The three public health variables--frequently wearing a mask in public places (adjusted OR = 0.36, p < 0.001), washing hands >10 times a day (adjusted OR = 0.44, p = 0.008), and disinfecting the living quarters thoroughly (adjusted OR = 0.36, p < 0.001)--remained significant protective factors.

A number of protective factors were related to relevant public health measures, including the frequency of using a face mask in public venues, the frequency of washing hands each day, and disinfection of living quarters thoroughly during the same period.

On the other hand, using a mask frequently in public places (OR = 0.27, p < 0.001), washing one's hands >10 times a day (OR = 0.58, p = 0.008), and disinfecting the living quarters thoroughly (OR = 0.41, p < 0.001) during the reference period were significant protective factors (Table 2).
explanation: The evidence directly states that frequent mask use in public venues, frequent hand washing, and disinfecting the living quarters were significant protective factors against a specific event. The claim is supported by this statement.

statement: U.s. to suspend visa services in virus-hit countries including japan
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: (File photo) [Getty/Kyodo] Beginning Thursday, the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo and all consulates in Japan will suspend routine nonimmigrant visa appointments, while most services for U.S. citizens will continue.

The State Department decided to suspend visa services in "response to worldwide challenges related to the outbreak of COVID-19," with countries subject to travel advisories higher than level 1 set to be affected, the U.S. Embassy in South Korea said in a statement.
In South Korea, the U.S. embassy said it will cancel all routine immigrant and nonimmigrant visa appointments as of Thursday.
The travel advisory for Japan is at level 2, which calls for U.S. citizens to "exercise increased caution," while that for South Korea is at level 3, or "reconsider travel."
explanation: The evidence states that the U.S. Embassy in Tokyo and all consulates in Japan will suspend routine nonimmigrant visa appointments, while most services for U.S. citizens will continue, as a response to worldwide challenges related to the outbreak of COVID-19. statement: Significant expression of furin and ace2 on oral epithelial cells may facilitate the efficiency of 2019-ncov entry
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Conclusions Based on these findings, we speculated that 2019-nCov could effectively invade oral mucosal cells though two possible routes: binding to the ACE2 receptor and fusion with cell membrane activated by FURIN protease.
Our results indicated that oral mucosa tissues are susceptible to 2019-nCov, which provides valuable information for virus-prevention strategy in clinical care as well as daily life.

Results The bioinformatics results indicated the differential expression of ACE2 and FURIN on epithelial cells of different oral mucosal tissues and the proportion of FURIN-positive cells was obviously higher than that of ACE2-positive cells.

The S-glycoprotein, which recognized as the key factor for the entry of 2019-nCov into the cell, contains two functional domains: an ACE2 receptor binding domain and a second domain necessary for fusion of the coronavirus and cell membranes.

statement: Politician raises alarm over trudeau govt 's plan to build covid quarantine/isolation camps
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Randy Hillier, Independent Ontario MPP for Lanark, Frontenac & Kingston, expressed concern over the "Federal Quarantine/Isolation sites" in the provincial question period late this week.
"The expansion of isolation/quarantine camps in Canada is something of concern and the Ontario government must know about it, so why won't they tell the people of Ontario?"

"So your government must be in negotiations and aware of these plans to potentially detain and isolate citizens and residents of our country and our province, so speaker, to the Premier, where will these camps be built, how many people will be detained, and for what reason, for what reasons can people be kept in these isolation camps, and I'd like to have the Premier assure the people of Ontario," said Hillier, whose microphone was cut off before he could finish.
explanation: The evidence provided shows that a politician expressed concern over 'Federal Quarantine/Isolation sites', but it does not confirm the claim about the Trudeau government's plan to build COVID-19 quarantine/isolation camps. The evidence only indicates that there are concerns and questions raised, but it does not provide any substantiated information about a plan by the Trudeau government.

statement: Cdc announces modifications and extension of no sail order for all cruise ships
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: This order ceases operations of cruise ships in waters in which the United States may exert jurisdiction and requires that they develop a comprehensive, detailed operational plan approved by CDC and the USCG to address the COVID-19 pandemic through maritime focused solutions, including a fully implementable response plan with limited reliance on state, local, and federal government support.
Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA) voluntarily suspended cruise ship operations in March in conjunction with the earlier No Sail Order issued March 14.

The CDC, the U.S. Coast Guard, and the Department of Homeland Security have been working with the industry to determine the most appropriate public health strategy to limit the impact of COVID-19 at cruise ship ports of entry in the United States.
The No Sail Order reinforces the strong action by President Donald J. Trump and the White House Coronavirus Task Force to combat the spread of COVID-19 in the United States.
explanation: The evidence indicates that the CDC has announced modifications and extension of a no sail order for all cruise ships operating in waters under US jurisdiction. The order requires the development of a comprehensive operational plan to address COVID-19, which suggests an ongoing or extended restriction on cruises. Furthermore, the CLIA's voluntary suspension of operations in March aligns with the initial no sail order issued by the CDC on March 14.

statement: Afucosylated immunoglobulin g responses are a hallmark of enveloped virus infections and show an exacerbated phenotype in covid-19
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Here, we report that afucosylated IgG which are of minor abundance in humans (6% of total IgG) are specifically formed against surface epitopes of enveloped viruses after natural infections or immunization with attenuated viruses, while protein subunit immunization does not elicit this low fucose response.
In the case of COVID-19, the critically ill show aggravated afucosylated-IgG responses against the viral spike protein.
Our findings indicate antibody glycosylation as a potential factor in inflammation and protection in enveloped virus infections including COVID-19.
explanation: The evidence provided shows that afucosylated IgG responses are specifically formed against surface epitopes of enveloped viruses, including in the case of COVID-19. The critically ill patients show an aggravated response to these afucosylated-IgG against the viral spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. This supports the claim that afucosylated immunoglobulin G responses are a hallmark of enveloped virus infections and show an exacerbated phenotype in COVID-19.

statement: Covid-19 pandemic could end if 70 % of people wore masks consistently
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: "Even less efficient cloth masks could also slow the spread if worn consistently," Kumar added.
The performance of face masks worn for many hours, such as by health care or other essential workers, impact how effective overall mask wearing can be, the researchers added.

Singapore : The COVID-19 pandemic could end if at least 70% of the people wore face masks in public consistently, according to a review of studies which suggests that the type of material used and the duration of mask use play key roles in their effectiveness.

statement: Risk of covid-19 hospitalisation rises exponentially with age , inversely proportional to t-cell production
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: This mirrors the well studied exponential decline of both thymus volume and T-cell production, which halve every 16 years.

The strikingly simple inverse relationship between COVID-19 risk and thymic T-cell output reported here begs a mechanistic understanding and suggests that T-cell based therapies may be a promising target.

In addition, incidence of severe disease and mortality due to COVID-19 are both higher in men, consistent with the degree to which thymic involution (and the decrease in T-cell production with age) is more severe in men compared to women.
explanation: The evidence indicates that both COVID-19 risk and thymic T-cell output show an inverse relationship: the higher the age, the lower the T-cell production, which can lead to increased COVID-19 hospitalization risk. The evidence also suggests that this inverse relationship is more pronounced in men compared to women.

statement: Researchers identify multiple molecules that shut down sars-cov-2 polymerase reaction
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: They then demonstrated that sofosbuvir and four other nucleotide analogues (the active triphosphate forms of the HIV inhibitors Alovudine, Zidovudine, Tenofovir alafenamide, and Emtricitabine) also inhibited the SARS-CoV-2 polymerase with different levels of efficiency.

While all 11 molecules tested displayed incorporation, six exhibited immediate termination of the polymerase reaction, two showed delayed termination, and three did not terminate the polymerase reaction.

In an earlier set of experiments testing the properties of the polymerase of the coronavirus that causes SARS, the researchers found that the triphosphate of sofosbuvir was able to terminate the virus polymerase reaction.

Researchers at Columbia Engineering and the University of Wisconsin-Madison have identified a library of molecules that shut down the SARS-CoV-2 polymerase reaction, a key step that establishes the potential of these molecules as lead compounds to be further modified for the development of COVID-19 therapeutics.
explanation: The evidence indicates that researchers have identified multiple molecules (including sofosbuvir) that inhibit the SARS-CoV-2 polymerase reaction, which is a key step in viral replication. The molecules are referred to as potential lead compounds for developing COVID-19 therapeutics.

statement: Full-dose clot prophylaxis halted for severe covid-19 in nhlbi trial.
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Cite this: COVID-19 Anticoagulation Trials 'Paused' for Futility, Safety - Medscape - Dec 22, 2020.
Therapeutic dosing was safe in this moderately ill COVID-19 population, unlike in the critically ill population for which the trials halted the full-dose strategy after seeing signals of harm.

All three trials have paused enrollment of critically ill COVID-19 patients requiring intensive care unit support for whom therapeutic doses of anticoagulation drugs did not reduce the need for organ support, the NHLBI statement notes.
Informed by the deliberations of the data safety monitoring boards of these trials, all of the trial sites have paused enrollment of the most critically ill hospitalized patients with COVID-19.

statement: Serological responses to human virome define clinical outcomes of italian patients infected with sars-cov-2.
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Here, we studied 159 hospitalized Italian patients with pneumonia from the NIAID-NCI COVID-19 Consortium using a phage-display method to characterize circulating antibodies binding to 93,904 viral peptides encoded by 1,276 strains of human viruses.
explanation: The evidence provided describes a study that analyzed antibody responses to a wide range of human viral peptides in 159 Italian COVID-19 patients with pneumonia. However, it does not directly establish a relationship between these serological responses and clinical outcomes specifically for SARS-CoV-2 infection.

statement: Serological responses to bacterial virome define clinical outcomes of italian patients infected with sars-cov-2.
label: NOT_SUPPORTED

explanation: The provided evidence studies antibody responses in Italian patients with pneumonia caused by SARS-CoV-2 using a phage-display method to characterize circulating antibodies binding to various viral peptides. However, the claim specifically states that serological responses to bacterial virome (bacteria) define clinical outcomes of Italian patients infected with SARS-CoV-2. The evidence does not support this claim as it focuses on viral peptides, not bacterial ones.

statement: The human brain vasculature shows a distinct expression pattern of sars-cov-2 entry factors
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Our study serves as a publicly available single-cell atlas of SARS-CoV-2 related entry factors and interaction partners in human and mouse brain endothelial- and perivascular cells, which can be employed for future studies in clinical samples of COVID-19 patients.

We observed a distinct expression pattern of the cathepsins B (CTSB) and -L (CTSL) - which are able to substitute for the ACE2 co-receptor TMPRSS2 - in the human vasculature with CTSB being mainly expressed in the brain vasculature and CTSL predominantly in the peripheral vasculature, and these observations were confirmed at the protein level in the Human Protein Atlas and using immunofluorescence stainings.

This expression pattern of SARS-CoV-2 viral-entry associated proteases and SARS-CoV-2 interaction partners was also present in endothelial cells and microglia in the fetal brain, suggesting a developmentally established SARS-CoV-2 entry machinery in the human vasculature.

At both the adult and fetal stages, we detected a distinct pattern of SARS-CoV-2 entry associated genes transcripts in brain vascular endothelial cells and microglia, providing a potential explanation for an inflammatory response in the brain endothelium upon SARS-CoV-2 infection.
explanation: The evidence presents a study that examines the expression pattern of cathepsins B (CTSB) and -L (CTSL), which can function as SARS-CoV-2 entry factors in human brain vasculature. The expression pattern is supported at both the mRNA and protein levels, and the distinct expression in brain vasculature is also observed in fetal brain endothelial cells and microglia.

label: SUPPORTED

statement: Modified vaccinia ankara based sars-cov-2 vaccine expressing full-length spike induces strong neutralizing antibody response
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Following immunizations with MVA/S or MVA/S1, both spike protein recombinants induced strong IgG antibodies to purified full-length SARS-CoV-2 spike protein.
These results demonstrate MVA/S is a potential vaccine candidate against SARS-CoV-2 infection.
The MVA/S induced a robust antibody response to purified RBD, S1 and S2 whereas MVA/S1 induced an antibody response to the S1 region outside of the RBD region.
explanation: The evidence provided shows that immunizations with MVA/S (Modified vaccinia ankara based sars-cov-2 vaccine expressing full-length spike) induce a strong IgG antibody response to purified full-length SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. This suggests the claim that Modified vaccinia ankara based sars-cov-2 vaccine expressing full-length spike induces strong neutralizing antibody response is supported.

statement: Modified vaccinia ankara based sars-cov-2 vaccine lacking full-length spike induces strong neutralizing antibody response
label: NOT_SUPPORTED
evidences: Following immunizations with MVA/S or MVA/S1, both spike protein recombinants induced strong IgG antibodies to purified full-length SARS-CoV-2 spike protein.
These results demonstrate MVA/S is a potential vaccine candidate against SARS-CoV-2 infection.
The MVA/S induced a robust antibody response to purified RBD, S1 and S2 whereas MVA/S1 induced an antibody response to the S1 region outside of the RBD region.
explanation: The claim 'Modified vaccinia ankara based sars-cov-2 vaccine lacking full-length spike induces strong neutralizing antibody response' is supported by the provided evidence. The evidence shows that immunizations with MVA/S (modified vaccinia ankara based on SARS-CoV-2 spike protein) induced a strong IgG antibody response to the purified full-length SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, demonstrating its potential as a vaccine candidate against SARS-CoV-2 infection. The evidence also indicates that MVA/S induced a robust antibody response to purified RBD, S1 and S2 regions of the spike protein, while MVA/S1 only induced an antibody response to the S1 region outside of the RBD region.

statement: Novel mutation identified in sars-cov-2 spike protein from sweden
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: The mutation changes an arginine residue to a histidine residue at position 364 in the S1 subunit of the viral spike protein.
The mutation is located at the surface of the S1 subunit of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, the main surface structure the virus uses to gain entry to host cells.
SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences from late April in Stockholm, Sweden reveal a novel mutation in the spike protein.

Tatiany Soratto and colleagues from the Karolinska Institutet, Sweden, and the Federal University of Santa Catarina, in Brazil, say it is possible the unknown mutation could affect the ability of the virus to bind to host cells.
explanation: The evidence provided indicates that a novel mutation was identified in the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 from Stockholm, Sweden. This mutation changes an arginine residue to a histidine residue at position 364 in the S1 subunit of the viral spike protein, which is located on the surface of the protein and crucial for cell entry. The authors also suggest that this mutation could affect the ability of the virus to bind to host cells.

statement: Our main findings are that cardiac involvement may occur with covid-19 even without respiratory tract signs and symptoms of infection .
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Heart palpitations have been reported to be the main presenting symptom of COVID-19 in patients without a fever or cough82.
Patients with COVID-19 infection can present with symptoms mimicking CV events, including chest pain, dyspnoea, and shock, even in the absence of cardiac injury.

An autopsy of a patient with COVID-19 and ARDS who died of a sudden cardiac arrest showed no evidence of myocardial structural involvement, suggesting that COVID-19 did not directly impair the heart57.
These observations suggest that COVID-19 can cause ACS even in the absence of substantial systemic inflammation.
explanation: The evidence provided indicates that heart palpitations and symptoms mimicking CV events (such as chest pain, dyspnea, and shock) have been reported in patients with COVID-19 who do not exhibit respiratory tract signs or symptoms of infection. Additionally, an autopsy of a patient with COVID-19 did not reveal evidence of myocardial structural involvement, suggesting that the heart was not directly impaired by the virus. These findings collectively support the claim that cardiac involvement may occur with COVID-19 even in the absence of respiratory tract signs and symptoms.

statement: Our main findings are that cardiac involvement cannot occur with covid-19 even without respiratory tract signs and symptoms of infection.
label: NOT_SUPPORTED

An autopsy of a patient with COVID-19 and ARDS who died of a sudden cardiac arrest showed no evidence of myocardial structural involvement, suggesting that COVID-19 did not directly impair the heart57.
These observations suggest that COVID-19 can cause ACS even in the absence of substantial systemic inflammation.
explanation: The evidence provided suggests that heart palpitations and other CV event-mimicking symptoms can occur in COVID-19 patients without respiratory signs, and cardiac arrest has been observed even with no myocardial structural involvement. However, the evidence does not establish that 'cardiac involvement cannot occur' with COVID-19.

statement: Sars-cov-2 viroporin triggers the nlrp3 inflammatory pathway
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: We report that the SARS-CoV-2 viroporin encoded by ORF3a activates the NLRP3 inflammasome, the most promiscuous of known inflammasomes.

In a pared-down system, we investigate the influence of ORF3a, an essential SARS-CoV-2 protein, on the inflammatory machinery and find that it activates NLRP3, the most prominent inflammasome by causing potassium loss across the cell membrane.
explanation: The claim is directly stated and supported in the evidence: 'We report that the SARS-CoV-2 viroporin encoded by ORF3a activates the NLRP3 inflammasome.' Additionally, the evidence also provides a rationale for this activation (causing potassium loss across the cell membrane).

statement: Cepi and sk bioscience extend collaboration to develop next generation covid-19 vaccine
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: CEPI has also partnered with bioscience facilities SK bioscience and GC Pharma to reserve manufacturing capacities exclusively for one or more CEPI-funded COVID-19 vaccines.
Im pleased to expand our partnership with SK bioscience to develop their vaccine candidate, GBP510, which marks CEPIs first investment in Wave 2 vaccines.

For the COVID-19 vaccine response, SK bioscience is undergoing development for its vaccine candidate against SARS- CoV-2 with support from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and CEPI, and using its established development and manufacturing capabilities, it has recently agreed to develop and manufacture AstraZenecas and Novavaxs COVID-19 vaccine candidates.

SK bioscience and CEPI are committed to global equitable access of COVID-19 vaccines and have agreed that this vaccine candidate will be made available for procurement and allocation, if proven to be safe and effective, through the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access (COVAX) Facility.
explanation: The evidence indicates a collaboration between Cepi and Sk bioscience to develop a next-generation Covid-19 vaccine. The text mentions that CEPI has partnered with SK bioscience for the development of their vaccine candidate GBP510, which is described as a Wave 2 vaccine in response to Covid-19. Additionally, it is stated that SK bioscience is undergoing development for its vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 with support from CEPI and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, and that they have agreed to develop and manufacture AstraZeneca's and Novavax's Covid-19 vaccine candidates. Lastly, it is mentioned that this collaboration is committed to global equitable access of Covid-19 vaccines through the COVAX Facility.

statement: Cepi and sk bioscience extend collaboration to develop first generation covid-19 vaccine
label: NOT_SUPPORTED
evidences: CEPI has also partnered with bioscience facilities SK bioscience and GC Pharma to reserve manufacturing capacities exclusively for one or more CEPI-funded COVID-19 vaccines.
Im pleased to expand our partnership with SK bioscience to develop their vaccine candidate, GBP510, which marks CEPIs first investment in Wave 2 vaccines.

For the COVID-19 vaccine response, SK bioscience is undergoing development for its vaccine candidate against SARS- CoV-2 with support from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and CEPI, and using its established development and manufacturing capabilities, it has recently agreed to develop and manufacture AstraZenecas and Novavaxs COVID-19 vaccine candidates.

SK bioscience and CEPI are committed to global equitable access of COVID-19 vaccines and have agreed that this vaccine candidate will be made available for procurement and allocation, if proven to be safe and effective, through the COVID-19 Vaccine Global Access (COVAX) Facility.
explanation: The evidence provided indicates a partnership between CEPI and SK bioscience for the development of a COVID-19 vaccine. The passage mentions CEPI's investment in SK bioscience's GBP510 vaccine candidate, which is their first Wave 2 vaccine, and also states that SK bioscience is developing and manufacturing AstraZeneca's and Novavax's COVID-19 vaccine candidates with support from CEPI. Furthermore, the commitment to global equitable access of COVID-19 vaccines through the COVAX Facility also supports this claim.

statement: Sars-cov-2 evolved into two major types
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: term these two types L and S type: two major types (L and S types): the S type is ancestral, and the L type evolved from S type.
We hypothesized that the two types of SARS-CoV-2 viruses might have experienced different selective pressures due to different epidemiological features.
explanation: The provided evidence only indicates the existence of two types (L and S) of SARS-CoV-2 viruses, with one being ancestral (the S type), and another evolving from it (the L type). However, the evidence does not provide any concrete support or detail on whether these two types can be categorized as 'major types.' Additional evidence such as genetic analysis, epidemiological data, or studies would be necessary to confirm that these two types are indeed 'major' types of SARS-CoV-2.

statement: A bra manufacturer has begun making masks , instead of bras
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: Share The worlds leading manufacturer of respirator masks may have originally intended them to be bras.
The shift came when an employee realized that the bra materials were similar to ones used in masks.

Companies create lacy masks out of BRAS after people started turning their old lingerie into makeshift PPE People have been making their own face masks out of bras Molded bra cups actually inspired the N95 mask, though these homemade versions offer considerably less protection A Japanese lingerie company is also selling masks made from their bra materials In the US, the $39.99 Emergency Bra 'can be transformed into two facemasks to reduce the inhalation of harmful chemical, biohazard and dust particulate' By Carly Stern For Dailymail.com Published: 16:45 EST, 29 April 2020
Fast Company points out that it's actually not so surprising that masks are being made from bras  since bras inspired the N95 mask.
explanation: The evidence suggests that a bra manufacturer has indeed begun making masks. The text mentions the shift from manufacturing bras to masks, and provides examples of companies creating lacy masks out of bras, selling masks made from bra materials, and even producing an emergency bra that can be transformed into two facemasks. Additionally, it is stated that bras inspired the N95 mask.

statement: Higher ace2 expression found in fat and cancer cells
label: SUPPORTED
evidences: ACE2 expression correlated with increased macrophage abundance in some tumors, while TMPRSS2 was strongly associated with epithelial cells.
Results Matched normal tissues generally display higher ACE2 and TMPRSS2 expression compared with cancer, with normal and tumor from digestive organs expressing the highest levels.
The expression of ACE2 and TMPRSS2 was significantly higher in normal tissues relative to tumors (figure 1C).

By the search for network database and re-analysis of pubic data, we found the level of ACE2 expression in adipose tissue was higher than that in lung tissue, which indicated the adipose tissue might be vulnerable to SARS-CoV-2 as well; the levels of ACE2 expressed by adipocytes and adipose progenitor cells were similar between non-obese individuals and obese individuals, but obese individuals have more adiposes so as to increase the number of ACE2-expressing cells; the expression of ACE2 in tumor tissues posed by five different types of cancers increased significantly compared with that in adjacent tissues.
explanation: The evidence indicates that ACE2 expression is found in higher levels in fat and cancer cells compared to normal tissues. This conclusion is based on the observations of increased ACE2 expression in adipose tissue compared to lung tissue, as well as the observation that obese individuals, who have more adipose tissue, have an increase in the number of ACE2-expressing cells. Additionally, the evidence shows that the expression of ACE2 in tumor tissues posed by five different types of cancers increased significantly compared with that in adjacent tissues.
